properties.Description: Janurary: Three men hanged. One for alleged horse theft. Dry Diggings given the new name of "Hangtown."
Burning of enslaved man for allegedly murdering master
properties.Source: Orville W. Taylor, Negro Slavery on Arkansas (Durham, N.C.: Duke University Press, 1958), 235 as listed in Pfiefer, Roots of Rough Justice.
properties.Target Classification: Black; Slave; Alleged Criminal; Alleged Murderer

properties.Description: May: Astor Place Riot. Long-time feud between William C. MacReady and Edwin Forrest led to major theater riot. When MacReady attempted to act MacBeth he was not only shouted offstage, but the crowd outside began to riot. Troops were brought in. Fired once over heads, but then had to fire directly into crowd. 22 died, 48 wounded. 50 to 70 police injured. Next night protest against force easily quelled. Some 300 police and 200 state militia involved.
properties.Source: Cook.Armies, p.24-27
properties.Target Classification: Theater; Actor; Legal; Law Officer; Military; Militia

properties.Description: June: Fire purposefully set so a gang could attack Franklin Hose company on its way to the fire. That night the Franklin Hose company retaliated, attacking the Moyamensing Hose. Shots exchanged, one man killed, 9 or 10 wounded.
properties.Source: Scharf and Wescott, p.691-692
properties.Target Classification: Firefighter; Franklin Hose; Gang

properties.Description: July: Flatheads and Regulators fight at Linn Farm. Two flatheads killed and four wounded. One regulator killed and two wounded.
properties.Source: Eteheson. "Good Men," p.17;Lethal Imagination, p.161
properties.Target Classification: Vigilante; Regulator (Vigilante); Gang; Flathead

properties.Description: July: Regulators and Flatheads battle it out about 150 men engaged. Three men killed; two Flatheads, one Regulator.
properties.Source: Brumbaugh. "Regulator Movement," p.55-56
properties.Target Classification: Vigilante; Regulator (Vigilante); Gang; Flathead

properties.Description: July: John Wilson killed for alleged horse theft
properties.Source: Dubuque Weekly Miner's Express, July 25, 1849 as listed in Pfeifer, The Roots of Rough Justice.
properties.Target Classification: Alleged Criminal; Alleged Thief; Alleged Horse Thief

properties.Description: October: Post-election riot at the California House pub led to race fighting leaving several black and white people dead. Fire set to California House spread to several other buildings. Rioters fight firemen. Two firemen killed, one Irishman, and one black boy. At least nine whites and 16 blacks injured. African Americans attempted to fight back at California house and elsewhere. Militia called out to quell riot.
properties.Source: Feldsburg.Philadelpha Riots, p.5
properties.Target Classification: Irish; Catholic; Black; Firefighter; Youth

properties.Description: December: Yankee miners drive a Chilean party out, hanged the major (??), whipped several others and cropped the ears of still others. At one point before these punishments, an American had been killed.
properties.Source: No source given
properties.Target Classification: Chilean; Hispanic; Catholic
properties.Actions: Lethal Violence; Non-Lethal Violence; Humiliation; Mutilation

properties.Description: July: Hanging of unnamed Native man for allegedly stabbing a lumberjack
properties.Source: Western Historical Company, History of Northern Wisconsin (Chicago, 1881), 195 as listed in Pfeifer, The Roots of Rough Justice.
properties.Target Classification: Native; Alleged Criminal; Alleged Assailant

properties.Description: Summer: Company of veterans called "the Hounds" attack hispanics from Chile, Peru, and Mexico. At least one killed.
properties.Source: Pitt. "Beginnings of Nativism," p.26
properties.Target Classification: Chilean; Hispanic; Catholic; Mexican; Peruvian

properties.Description: December: A Mexican hanged for alleged theft.
properties.Source: Placer Times (Auburn), 19 Jan. 1850; Rough Abstract of a Forty-Niner Diary as listed in Carrigan and Webb, Forgotten Dead.
properties.Target Classification: Mexican; Hispanic; Catholic; Alleged Criminal; Alleged Thief

properties.Description: Late: Unknown Mexican hanged for allegedly stealing a mule.
properties.Source: Calif. Historical Marker 446; Weston, Mother Lode Album as listed in William D. Carrigan and Clive Webb, Forgotten Dead: Mob Violence against Mexicans in the United States, 1848-1928 (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2013).
properties.Target Classification: Mexican; Hispanic; Catholic; Alleged Criminal; Alleged Thief

properties.Description: August: Striking tailors ransack a store that made non-union clothing. Police intervened and a general battle ensued. Two strikers fatally wounded, others seriously injured. 32 German tailors arrested and ultimately plead guilty to A+B. Fines levied ranging from $5 to $50.
properties.Source: Degler. "Labor," p.81
properties.Target Classification: Worker; Tailor; Non-Union; Strikebreaker; Legal; Law Officer

properties.Description: August: A party of 40 squatters attempted to regain possession of property one of their number had been evicted from. The sheriff and his men opposed them. A gun battle ensued. At least two died and several wounded. On the next day, when the sheriff attempted to arrest several of tese rioters at a hotel, another gun battle erupted. The sheriff was killed, while two squatters perished.
properties.Target Classification: Legal; Law Officer; Sheriff

properties.Description: January: A small group of men whipped and then killed Juan Chapa Guerra under the mistaken impression that he was Juan Chapa García.
properties.Source: Report of the Committee of Investigation of the Mexican Government as listed in Carrigan and Webb, Forgotten Dead.
properties.Target Classification: Mexican; Hispanic; Catholic
properties.Persons Named as Targets: Juan Chapa Guerra; Juan Chapa García

properties.Description: May: Hanging of enslaved woman for allegedly assualting mistress with an ax
properties.Source: R. Douglas Hurt, Agriculture and Slavery in Missouri's Little Dixie (Columbia, MO: University of Missouri Press, 1992), 248 as listed in Pfeifer, The Roots of Rough Justice.
properties.Target Classification: Black; Slave; Woman; Alleged Criminal; Alleged Assailant

properties.Description: June: A black man named Grayson arrested for the murder of David W. Miller on "wholly insufficient" evidence. After the murder, "bystanders, under the great excitement of the moment, forgetful of the mild spirit of our law" tortured the accused man. Statements made during this torture used against Grayson. The court ordered a new trial, but a mob stormed the jail and hanged Grayson themselves.
properties.Source: Supreme Court of Appeals of Virginia, 1850-1851 Cases: Volume VII, 318-319
properties.Target Classification: Black; Legal; Jail; Alleged Criminal; Alleged Murderer

properties.Description: July: Hanging of Francisco Flores for alleged murder.
properties.Source: Wisconsin Democrat, Aug. 1850 as listed in Carrigan and Webb, Forgotten Dead.
properties.Target Classification: Mexican; Hispanic; Catholic; Alleged Criminal; Alleged Murderer

properties.Description: January: A mob of 500 anglos and 200 "foreigners" hanged a man named Pablo for alleged murder.
properties.Source: Sacremento Transcript, 21 Jan 1851 as listed in Carrigan and Webb, Forgotten Dead.
properties.Target Classification: Mexican; Hispanic; Catholic; Alleged Criminal; Alleged Murderer

properties.Description: Hanging of Jarrett, and enslaved man, for alleged rape
properties.Source: Wyatt-Brown, Southern Honor, 389 as listed in Pfeifer, Roots of Rough Justice.
properties.Target Classification: Black; Alleged Criminal; Alleged Sexual Assailant

properties.Description: April: An organized company of French soldiers forcibly ejected by 900 Americans storming their encampment. Two French and one American killed.
properties.Source: Pitt. "Beginnings of Nativism," p.34
properties.Target Classification: French; Catholic; Military

properties.Description: May: Rowides assault large body of Turnverein Germans celebrating Pentecost with a picnic. Germans counter-attacked, and drove the rowdies off. Germans demolished furnishing of house where rowdies hid. Rowdies destroyed a German's house. Reinforced, the rowdies continued the battle and tried to prevent the Germans from returning to NYC. At least one killed, maybe as many as 4. Plenty more wounded.
properties.Target Classification: American; German
properties.Actions: Lethal Violence; Property Destroyed; Non-Lethal Violence

properties.Description: June: Anglo vigilance committee hanged a Mexican man for alleged murder.
properties.Source: Carrigan and Webb, Forgotten Dead.
properties.Target Classification: Mexican; Hispanic; Catholic; Alleged Criminal; Alleged Murderer

properties.Description: June: On 15 June, a crowd of between one and three thousand lynched Antonio Cruz and Patricio Janori for the alleged murder of an Anglo.
properties.Source: San Francisco Herald, 28 June and 1 July 1851 as listed in Carrigan and Webb, Forgotten Dead.
properties.Target Classification: Mexican; Hispanic; Catholic; Alleged Criminal; Alleged Murderer

properties.Description: June: After a merchant caught an Australian thief robbing his safe, a group of merchants held a vigilante trial, found the man guilty and hanged him. One of the leaders cried, at the moment of execution, "Every lover of liberty and good order lay hold of this rope."
properties.Source: Senkewicz.Vigilantes, p.5
properties.Target Classification: Australian; Thief

properties.Description: July: Miners lynched a Mexican woman, Josefa Segovia, because she was an "evil body who corrupted innocent young American men."
properties.Source: Pitt. "Beginnings of Nativism," p.34 and Carrigan and Webb, Forgotten Dead.
properties.Target Classification: Mexican; Hispanic; Woman; Catholic

properties.Description: July: Hanging of enslaved man for alleged murder
properties.Source: Enda Junkins, "Slave Plots, Insurrections, and Acts of Violence in the State of Texas, 1828-1865" (MA thesis, Baylor University, 1969), 40 as listed in Pfeifer, The Roots of Rough Justice.
properties.Target Classification: Black; Slave; Alleged Criminal; Alleged Murderer

properties.Description: August: Vigilantes "rescue and murder two prisoners."
properties.Source: Senkewicz.Vigilantes, p.89
properties.Target Classification: Prisoner; Legal; Jail

properties.Description: September: A marshal, a posse and a slave owner attempt to get fugitive slaves at William Parker's. 15-25 black people engage in a gun battle with them. One white person - the slave owner - killed, several others seriously wounded.
properties.Source: Katz.Resistance at Christiana
properties.Target Classification: Slavecatcher; Slaveholder; Legal; Law Officer; Marshal

properties.Description: November: On the 15th, a man named Domingo lynched by a mob for alleged murder.

properties.Target Classification: Mexican; Hispanic; Catholic; Alleged Criminal; Alleged Murderer

properties.Description: December: On the 22nd, two Mexicans hanged by a vigilance committee for alleged murder.

properties.Description: November: Mexican-American bandits kill local judge. Some bandits apprehended. Several taken from court house and hanged.
properties.Source: Bleen. "Vigilantism," 57 (1972), 17
properties.Rioter Classification: Mexican; American; Hispanic; Vigilante; Alleged Bandit; ALleged Criminal
properties.Target Classification: Legal; Judge; Prisoner; Mexican; American; Hispanic; Alleged Bandit; Alleged Criminal

properties.Target Classification: Mexican; Hispanic; Catholic; Alleged Criminal; Alleged Murderer

properties.Description: April: On the 1st, A vigilance committee convicted and hanged Carlos Esclava for alleged theft. A crowd of between 800 and 1000 estimated to be present.

properties.Target Classification: Mexican; Hispanic; Catholic; Alleged Criminal; Alleged Murderer; Legal

properties.Location: One hundred miles from Snelling, CA

properties.Description: May: Mob seized Baltimore Muir, tried him for the murder of a fellow traveller on a wagon train and hanged him.
properties.Source: Black.Lynching, p.182-183
properties.Target Classification: Unknown

properties.Description: December: Irish canal workers, angered by a 20% cut in pay, attacked the contractor's house and beat him to a pulp. Before order could be restored, authorities killed one rioter.
properties.Source: Grimsted. "Antebellum Workers," p.10,11,23,24;NY Tribune, December 15, 1852
properties.Target Classification: Contractor

properties.Description: May: Large crowd attempts to break into the courthouse to free fugitive slave Anthony Burns. During the attempt, some shots fired, killing one of the deputies.

properties.Description: August: Nativist riot lasting several days. Claim that an Irishman stabbed an American in the back led to Nativist attack on Irish neighborhood. 50-60 houses destroyed with axes, etc. Irish fought back. 8-10 killed, many injured. Began August 7th, election day.
properties.Source: McMaster, p.8,87; Billington, p.421
properties.Target Classification: Irish; Catholic
properties.Actions: Lethal Violence; Property Destroyed; Non-Lethal Violence

properties.Description: November: Two murderers sentenced separately to hanging. The Anglo was given a stay; the Mexican was hanged immediately. Mexicans angered at this difference in treatment stormed the jail and lynched the Anglo.
properties.Source: Bleen. "Vigilantism," p.20-21
properties.Target Classification: American; Prisoner; Protestant; Anglo; Legal; Jail

properties.Description: February: On the 11, Dollores and an unknown Mexican lynched for the alleged murder of an Anglo. Their bodies were left hanging from the tree to decompose.

properties.Description: April: Nativist election riots. On the 2nd a mob of 300-400 nativists invade German area and destroyed 1,300 German ballots because of reported ballot stuffing. Intermittent attacks on Germans and Irish followed. German barricaded the streets in the Over-the-Rhine area. When 400 nativists invaded on the night of the 3rd the Germans were well organized and trained, beat them back. Killing two. Scattered violence continued through the 4th.
properties.Source: Ross.Workers, p.188-189
properties.Target Classification: Irish; Catholic; German; Political
properties.Actions: Lethal Violence; Non-Lethal Violence; Threat; Property Destroyed

properties.Source: Johnson. (??), p.32
properties.Target Classification: Legal; Law Officer

Subsequently, the whites took up a collection to reimburse the MacDonald family for the cost of the slave.

properties.Description: August: Fire company riot. New Market and United Company planned an ambush of Mount Vernon Hook and Ladder Company. After a false alarm set by New Market, that company followed the Mount Vernon on its return. Some skirmishing occurred. But on Franklin street between Howard and Eutaw streets, the United attacked from the front. Pistols, bricks, axes, picks, and hooks used as Mount Vernon aided by the police drove off the assailants. Two mortally wounded, several others hurt.
properties.Source: Scharf.Chronicles, p.548
properties.Target Classification: Firefighter; Mount Vernon; Legal; Law Officer

properties.Description: May: Burning of black man for alleged murder and rape
properties.Source: New York Times, June 2, 1855; Sellers, Slavery in Alabama, 263 from Pfeifer, Roots of Rough Justice.
properties.Target Classification: Black; Alleged Murderer; Alleged Criminal; Alleged Sexual Assailant

properties.Description: July: A deputy constable shot a Mexican while seizing his guitar for debt. Natives rose in revolt, so Anglos organized their own committees. Some 11 prisoners given death sentences by summary court.
properties.Source: Blew. "Vigilantism," S. Cal Q., 54 (1972) 22
properties.Target Classification: Mexican; Hispanic; Catholic

properties.Description: July: Hanging of David F. Mayberry for alleged murder.
properties.Source: Democrat Standard (Janesville), July 12, 1855; Janesville Gazette, July 14, 1855 as listed in Pfeifer, The Roots of Rough Justice.
properties.Target Classification: Alleged Criminal; Alleged Murderer

properties.Description: August: Hanging of George DeBar for alleged murder.
properties.Source: Milwaukee Daily Free Democrat, August 8, 1855; Milwaukee Daily News, August 8, 1855 as listed in Pfeifer, The Roots of Rough Justice.
properties.Target Classification: Alleged Criminal; Alleged Murderer

properties.Description: August: An enslaved man named Bob lynched by hanging
properties.Source: Sellers, Slavery in Alabama, 263-264 as listed in Pfeifer, Roots of Rough Justice.
properties.Target Classification: Black; Slave

properties.Description: September: A riotous mob broke into a jail and lynched an enslaved man accused of rape and murder.
properties.Source: Waldrep, ed. Lynching in America, 74 as listed in Pfeifer, The Roots of Rough Justice and Weekly Law Gazette 4 (1859): 122-124.
properties.Target Classification: Black; Slave; Alleged Criminal; Alleged Murderer; Alleged Sexual Assailant; Legal; Jail

properties.Description: October: On the 19th, a vigilance committee hanged Francisco Tapia, Jesus Pino, Francisco Sanchez, and an unknown German for alleged theft.
properties.Source: New York Times, 29 Nov. 1855 as listed in Carrigan and Webb, Forgotten Dead.
properties.Target Classification: Mexican; Hispanic; Catholic; Alleged Criminal; Alleged Thief; German
properties.Persons Named as Targets: Francisco Tapia; Jesus Pino; Francisco Sanchez

properties.Description: October: "Slave of Judge Thomas Clingman" hanged for alleged murder of master
properties.Source: New York Times, October 16, 1855 as listed in Pfeifer, The Roots of Rough Justice.
properties.Target Classification: Black; Slave

properties.Description: December: On the 1st, an unknown Mexican taken from jail and hanged for alleged murder.
properties.Source: San Antonio Ledger, 22 Dec. 1855 as listed in Carrigan and Webb, Forgotten Dead.
properties.Target Classification: Mexican; Hispanic; Catholic; Alleged Criminal; Alleged Murderer; Legal; Jail

properties.Description: December: On Christmas Eve, an unknown Mexican was siezed from Law Officer and lynched for alleged cattle theft.
properties.Source: San Francisco Daily Placer Times, 30 Dec., 1855 as listed in Carrigan and Webb, Forgotten Dead.
properties.Target Classification: Mexican; Hispanic; Catholic; Alleged Criminal; Alleged Thief; Legal; Law Officer

properties.Description: January: When local pro-slavery rangers heard what happened at Easton, they captured free-soil captain Reese Brown. While they debated whether they should try him before killing him, one of the Rangers put an axe into Brown's skull. They deposited his body at his farm's door.
properties.Source: Nichols.Bleeding Kansas, p.82-83
properties.Target Classification: Free-Soiler; Anti-Slavery; Free-Stater

properties.Description: January: Free-soil election disrupted by pro-slave forces. Taunts led to threats and exchange of shots. A southerner was killed.
properties.Source: Nichols.Bleeding Kansas, p.82
properties.Target Classification: Free-Soiler; Anti-Slavery; Free-Stater

properties.Description: February: Hanging of A.F. Monroe for alleged murder
properties.Source: New York Times, February 22, 1856 as listed in Pfeifer, The Roots of Rough Justice.
properties.Target Classification: Alleged Murderer

properties.Description: February: Crowd took Mexican prisoners - one a bandit involved in 1855 revolt - out of jail and executed both by hanging.
properties.Source: Bleen. "Vigilantism," p.22
properties.Target Classification: Mexican; Hispanic; Catholic; Prisoner; Legal; Jail

properties.Description: May: On the 11th, three unknown Mexicans taken from jail and hanged for alleged murder, apparently with little proof.
properties.Source: Nevada Journal (Nevada City), 16 May 1856 as listed in Carrigan and Webb, Forgotten Dead.
properties.Target Classification: Mexican; Hispanic; Catholic; Alleged Criminal; Alleged Murderer; Legal; Jail; Prisoner

properties.Description: May: Eight free-soilers ambush 18 pro-slavery men, killing several.
properties.Source: Nichols.Bleeding Kansas, p.111
properties.Target Classification: Pro-Slavery; Border Ruffian; Political

properties.Description: May: Organization of S.F. vigilance committee by middle and upper class Protestants to counter Irish-Catholic political machine and violence. On May 12, Comm. Seized two accused murderers, tries and executes them. Committee then active in arresting and banishing others. Confronts governor's forces and wins. Tries and executes two others and disbands in August.
properties.Rioter Classification: American; Nativisit; Vigilante; Protestant; Vigilance Committee
properties.Target Classification: Irish; Catholic; Legal

properties.Description: May: John Brown and 8 followers visit three homes and execute 5 pro-slavery men (two were boys) in brutal massacre.
properties.Source: Nichols.Bleeding Kansas, p.110-119
properties.Type: Slavery; Vigilante; Law; Racial; Political; Land
properties.Target Classification: Pro-Slavery; Border Ruffian; Youth

properties.Description: May: Pro-slavery men, after capturing local minister, road into town to be met by 20 or 50 free-soil men, who fired upon them. Two men killed. Next day free-soil men, with John Brown and company attack Captain Pate's pro-slavery force of 50. Although free-soil men outnumbered, they capture Pate and half his men. Two opposing forces in area almost collide, but federal troops arrive and restore order.
properties.Source: Nichols.Bleeding Kansas, p.12-124
properties.Type: Slavery; Vigilante; Law; Racial; Political; Land
properties.Rioter Classification: Free-Soiler; Anti-Slavery; Free-Stater; Pro-Slavery; Border Ruffian; Vigilante
properties.Target Classification: Free-Soiler; Anti-Slavery; Free-Stater; Pro-Slavery; Border Ruffian; Religious; Minister

properties.Description: June: Unknown Mexican "hanged for stealing horses and robbing a church."
properties.Source: Galveston Weekly News, 8 July 1856 as listed in Carrigan and Webb, Forgotten Dead.
properties.Target Classification: Mexican; Hispanic; Catholic; Alleged Criminal; Alleged Thief; Alleged Horse Thief

properties.Description: June: Great deal of election rioting, mostly by know-nothings. At least two men killed and a score wounded. Maybe 4 men killed.
properties.Source: Billington, p.421; Asbury.French Quarter, p.295-296
properties.Target Classification: Unknown

properties.Description: June: Free soilers attack a half-built fort and a pro-slavery man killed.
properties.Source: Nichols.Bleeding Kansas, p.130
properties.Type: Slavery; Vigilante; Law; Racial; Political; Land
properties.Target Classification: Pro-Slavery; Border Ruffian; Vigilante

properties.Description: August: Free-soil men capture Fort Titus. One free-soiler killed, 2 pro-slavery killed. A cannon used. Titus captured and sent to Lawrence.
properties.Source: Nichols.Bleeding Kansas, p.137-139
properties.Type: Slavery; Vigilante; Law; Racial; Political; Land
properties.Target Classification: Pro-Slavery; Border Ruffian

properties.Description: August: Missourians under the leadership of General John Reid, at the invitation of pro-slavery interim governor attacked this free-soil town. Forty free-soilers ambushed them and resulting gun battle led to 5 free-soilerss killed, 3 wounded, and 2 killed and 3 wounded pro-slavery. After driving off the free-soil forces, pro-slavery men ran into Frederick Brown, John's son, and killed him. They then sacked the town. Shortly thereafter 2 larges forces (1300 each) fired a few volleys at each other and separated.
properties.Source: Nichols.Bleeding Kansas, p.135-136
properties.Type: Slavery; Vigilante; Law; Racial; Political; Land
properties.Target Classification: Free-Soiler; Anti-Slavery; Free-Stater
properties.Actions: Lethal Violence; Non-Lethal Violence; Property Destroyed

properties.Description: September: Pro-slavery forces called regulators attack William Phillips' house. He and his brother-in-law killed two, but Phillips was killed, too. Regulators also shipped 150 free-soilers down river that and the next day.
properties.Source: Nichols.Bleeding Kansas, p.149
properties.Type: Slavery; Vigilante; Law; Racial; Political; Land
properties.Target Classification: Free-Soiler; Anti-Slavery; Free-Stater

properties.Description: September: Free-soilers under John Swift attacked and captured the town. One defender had been killed. Four-pounder used. Later government troops capture free-soilers.
properties.Source: Nichols.Bleeding Kansas, p.154-155
properties.Type: Slavery; Vigilante; Law; Racial; Political; Land
properties.Target Classification: Pro-Slavery; Border Ruffian

properties.Description: September: "Rip-Rap" and Wanpawoag Clubs attack 17th ward house kept by James clar on Light street, opposite Warren. Bricks used and some shots fired. One man killed, several wounded during half hour battle. Police eventually disperse rioters Nativist battle.
properties.Source: Scharf.Chronicles, p.549; H+W, p.93
properties.Target Classification: Unknown

properties.Description: November: Serious election rioting throughout city, especially at 2nd and 8th ward polls. Eight killed, about 150 wounded as Democrats and know-nothings square off. Some common brought into play as know-nothings, despite strong democratic resistance, carry the day. Other reports (now Scharf) say 17 dead, 67 wounded.
properties.Source: Scharf.Chronicles, p.550-552
properties.Target Classification: Political; Nativist; Democrat; Know-Nothing

properties.Description: May: Vigilantes organize, they hang four men, expel many others, breaking up Irish Democratic machine.
properties.Source: Senkewicz.Vigilantes, p.156-188
properties.Target Classification: Irish; Catholic; Democrat; Political

properties.Description: October: José Castro hanged by Matt Tarpy and his vigilantes for alleged attempted murder. Tarpy and his men had to seize Castro from a group of Mexicans who tried to protect him.
properties.Source: Santa Cruz Pacific Sentinel, 1 and 15 Nov. 1856 as listed in Carrigan and Webb, Forgotten Dead.
properties.Target Classification: Mexican; Hispanic; Catholic; Alleged Criminal

properties.Description: November: Bill, a black man, hanged for alleged rape
properties.Source: New York Times, December 4, 1856 as listed in Pfeifer, The Roots of Rough Justice.
properties.Target Classification: Black; Alleged Criminal; Alleged Sexual Assailant

properties.Description: Burning of black man for alleged "sundry foul, revolting, and hellish crimes"
properties.Source: New York Times, Sept. 17, 1857.
properties.Target Classification: Black; Alleged Criminal

properties.Description: Hanging of George, an enslaved man for alleged murder
properties.Source: Cutler, Lynch-Law, 125; source: Liberator, October 16, 1857 as listed in Pfeifer, The Roots of Rough Justice.
properties.Target Classification: Black; Alleged Criminal; Alleged Murderer; Slave

properties.Description: Hanging of Bill, an enslaved man for alleged murder
properties.Source: Cutler, Lynch-Law, 125; source: Liberator, October 16, 1857 as listed in Pfeifer, The Roots of Rough Justice.
properties.Target Classification: Black; Alleged Criminal; Alleged Murderer; Slave

properties.Description: Burning of black man for alleged murder and rape
properties.Source: Bertram Wyatt-Brown, Southern Honor: Ethics and Behavior in the Old South (New York: Oxford University Press, 1982), 389 from Pfeifer, Roots of Rough Justice.
properties.Target Classification: Black; Alleged Criminal; Alleged Sexual Assailant; Alleged Murderer

properties.Description: January: On the 29th, a mob, angered by the death of an Anglo sheriff, hanged Juan Catabo, shot and decapitated Miguel Soto, and shot Diego Navarro, Pedro Lopez, Juan Valenzuela, and two unknown Mexicans.
properties.Source: Sonoma County Journal (Petulama), Feb. 20, 1857 as listed in Carrigan and Webb, Forgotten Dead.
properties.Target Classification: Mexican; Hispanic; Catholic; Alleged Criminal; Alleged Murderer
properties.Persons Named as Targets: Diego Navarro; Pedro Lopez; Juan Valenzuela; Miguel Soto; Juan Catabo

properties.Description: February: On the 2nd, Encarnacion Berreyesa hanged for alleged murder.
properties.Source: El Clamor Publico (Los Angeles), 28 Mar. and 9 May 1857 as listed in Carrigan and Webb, Forgotten Dead.
properties.Target Classification: Mexican; Hispanic; Catholic; Alleged Criminal; Alleged Murderer

properties.Description: February: On the 2nd, José Jesus Espinosa hanged for alleged murder.
properties.Source: New York Times, Mar. 17, 1857 as listed in Carrigan and Webb, Forgotten Dead.
properties.Target Classification: Mexican; Hispanic; Catholic; Alleged Criminal; Alleged Murderer

properties.Description: February: On the 3rd, Francisco or Guerro Ardillero hanged for alleged murder.
properties.Source: Los Angeles Star, 7 Feb 1857 as listed in Carrigan and Webb, Forgotten Dead.
properties.Target Classification: Mexican; Hispanic; Catholic; Alleged Criminal; Alleged Murderer

properties.Description: February: On the 6th, two unknown Mexicans hanged and one shot for alleged murder.
properties.Source: Sonoma County Journal (Petulama), Feb. 20, 1857 as listed in Carrigan and Webb, Forgotten Dead.
properties.Target Classification: Mexican; Hispanic; Catholic; Alleged Criminal; Alleged Murderer

properties.Description: February: On the 14th, Juan Flores hanged for alleged murder of Anglo sheriff.
properties.Source: Alta California (San Francisco), 2 March 1857 as listed in Carrigan and Webb, Forgotten Dead.
properties.Target Classification: Mexican; Hispanic; Catholic; Alleged Criminal; Alleged Murderer

properties.Description: February: On the 16th, a mob of two hundred seized José Anastacio García from jail and lynched him for alleged murder.
properties.Source: Santa Cruz Pacific Sentinel, 28 Feb. 1857; Santa Cruz Sentinel, 12 May 1877 as listed in Carrigan and Webb, Forgotten Dead.
properties.Target Classification: Mexican; Hispanic; Catholic; Alleged Criminal; Alleged Murderer; Legal; Jail; Prisoner

properties.Description: February: "Mexican Joe" hanged and decapitated for alleged murder.
properties.Source: Bartlett, ed. Reminiscences of a Ranger as listed in Carrigan and Webb, Forgotten Dead.
properties.Target Classification: Mexican; Hispanic; Catholic; Alleged Criminal; Alleged Murderer

properties.Description: February: José Santos hanged for alleged murder.
properties.Source: Pacific Sentinel, 21 Feb 1857 as listed in Carrigan and Webb, Forgotten Dead.
properties.Target Classification: Mexican; Hispanic; Catholic; Alleged Criminal; Alleged Murderer

properties.Description: March: On the 11th, Manuel Ribera was "shot through the bars of his jail cell" for alleged murder.
properties.Source: Sante Fe Weekly Gazette, 14 March 1857 as listed in Carrigan and Webb, Forgotten Dead.
properties.Target Classification: Mexican; Hispanic; Catholic; Alleged Criminal; Alleged Murderer; Legal; Jail; Prisoner

properties.Description: April: 8 unknown Mexicans lynched for alleged theft.
properties.Source: San Antonio Herald, 18 Apr. 1857 as listed in Carrigan and Webb, Forgotten Dead.
properties.Target Classification: Mexican; Hispanic; Catholic; Alleged Criminal; Alleged Thief

properties.Description: April: Iron Hills Vigilance Committee broke into jail and seized accused murderer Alexander Gifford. They forced him to confess. He claimed he had been hired to do the killing. The mob hanged Gifford anyway.
properties.Source: Black. "Lynchings," p.187
properties.Target Classification: Legal; Prisoner

properties.Description: May: Hanging of enslaved man for alleged attempted murder of mistress
properties.Source: Galveston Weekly News, May 17, 1859 as listed in Pfeifer, The Roots of Rough Justice.
properties.Target Classification: Black; Slave; Alleged Criminal

properties.Description: May: Mob seized 3 thieves from DeWitt jail in Clinton. They represented a Vigilance committee. They took the 3 to Andrew, the (??) headquarters. The mob quickly hanged William Barger, one of the thieves. They held the other two for trial. After trial they were whipped. One, Michael Carroll was then turned over to authorities; the other was banished.
properties.Source: Black. "Lynchings," p.188-190
properties.Target Classification: Legal; Prisoner; Thief; Jail
properties.Actions: Seized Person(s); Lethal Violence; Non-Lethal Violence; Threat; Extraction

properties.Description: May: Mob seized Boyd Wilkinson at his farm - actually he surrendered on the promise of being turned over to the authorities - for burning Philip Clark's barn. Clark and he had aruged over land claims. Placed in a wagon, he was drowned while crossing a river. 15 were arrested.
properties.Source: Black. "Lynchings," p.187-189
properties.Target Classification: Alleged Criminal; Alleged Arsonist

properties.Description: June: Regulators attacked the cabin of a man by the name of Corry. He was shot and killed apparently because Alonzo Page, one of the Regulators, had a personal grudge.
properties.Source: Graham. "Vigilance Committee," p.309
properties.Target Classification: Unknown

properties.Description: June: Regulator organization against horse thieves active. One member of the Regulators argued with Alonzo Page. Corry told the Regulators that Page was associated with horse thieves. The Regulators warned Page to leave the country. When he didn't, they came to his house night of June 18th and when Page resisted, he was shot. He died from the wounds.
properties.Source: Black. "Lynchings," p.192
properties.Target Classification: Vigilante; Regulator (Vigilante)

properties.Description: June: Mob seized Jacob A. Warner and accused him of being connected with a gang of outlaws. They tried him in a lynch court and then hanged him. At least 300 involved.
properties.Source: Black. "Lynchings," p.193-194
properties.Target Classification: Alleged Criminal; Alleged Outlaw

properties.Description: June: Band of Regulators capture Peter Conklin, chased and shot him and killed him.
properties.Source: Graham. "Vigilance Committee," p.366-367; Black. "Lynchings," p.194
properties.Target Classification: Unknown

properties.Description: June: Mob of about 60 took convicted horse thief from officials and hanged him.
properties.Source: Black. "Lynchings," p.194
properties.Target Classification: Prisoner; Legal; Alleged Criminal; Alleged Thief; Alleged Horse Thief

properties.Description: June: Hanging of Bennett Warren for alleged horse theft
properties.Source: Black, "Lynchings in Iowa," 192-194 as listed in Pfeifer, The Roots of Rough Justice.
properties.Target Classification: Alleged Criminal; Alleged Thief; Alleged Horse Thief

properties.Description: July: Regulators numbering about 200 broke into jail and took accused horse thieves Alonzo Gleeson and Edward Super. They held a trial for them. Super confessed. Both were hanged from a tree.
properties.Source: Black. "Lynchings," p.195
properties.Target Classification: Prisoner; Legal; Alleged Criminal; Alleged Thief; Alleged Horse Thief
properties.Actions: Seized Person(s); Lethal Violence; Prison Break

properties.Description: July: Bowery Boys and Dead Rabbits battle it out in the 6th ward. Arrival of Metropolitan Police had little effect. Beaten by the Dead Rabbits, only the arrival of a crowd of Bowery Boys enabled the Police to retreat. Twelve were killed, including two policemen. 41 injured. More fighting continued the next day and two regiments of militia needed to quell the disorder.
properties.Source: Cook.Armies, p.41
properties.Rioter Classification: Gang; Bowery Boy; Dead Rabbit; Nativist; American; Protestant; Irish; Catholic
properties.Target Classification: Gang; Bowery Boy; Dead Rabbit; Nativist; American; Protestant; Irish; Catholic; Legal; Law Officer; Military; Militia

properties.Description: July: Vigilance Committee wen to a Dr. Longs' believing he was connected to horse thieves. They found his brother and another man, whom they hanged. Long, however, escaped.
properties.Source: Black. "Lynchings," p.196
properties.Target Classification: Alleged Criminal; Alleged Thief; Alleged Horse Thief

properties.Description: July: Two Germans fighting collected a great crowd on the corner of 3rd street and Ave B. With the fight over two policemen arrived to disperse the crowd. When one man refused to move, a policeman clubb him. The crowd became threatening. Sergeant Lockwood arrived in the German area with seven more policemen and asserted his authority. He and the police were driven back under a hail of brickbats and rocks. More police arrived and clubbed their way through the crowd. They began to shoot. Crowd dispersed. One man killed.
properties.Source: Cook.Armies, p.44-45
properties.Target Classification: Legal; Law Officer

properties.Description: July: Vigilance committee captured a man named Kelso and an accomplice. They tried them and hanged them. When one of the crowd, a young farmer named Finch, came home and told his mother that he voted for hanging, she made him feel so bad that he went and hanged himself.
properties.Source: Black. "Lynchings," p.197
properties.Target Classification: Unknown

properties.Description: July: Mob of 400 from Mechanicsville seized a man charged with counterfeiting and horse stealing and held a lynch court. Then they hanged him. Search for another horse thief proved futile.
properties.Source: Black. "Lynchings," p.198
properties.Target Classification: Alleged Criminal; Alleged Thief; Alleged Horse Thief; Alleged Counterfeiter

properties.Description: July: Hanging of Jack Parrot for alleged horse theft
properties.Source: Dubuque Weekly Express and Herald, July 15, 1857; Dubuque Daily Times, July 13, 1857 as listed in Pfeifer, The Roots of Rough Justice.
properties.Target Classification: Alleged Criminal; Alleged Thief; Alleged Horse Thief

properties.Description: July: 2,000 citizens, over protest of pro-slave justice (??) and free soil mayor Adams, broke into the jail, took out 2 murderers and hanged them.
properties.Source: Nichols.Bleeding Kansas, p.197
properties.Type: Slavery; Vigilante; Law; Racial; Political; Land
properties.Target Classification: Legal; Prisoner; Alleged Criminal; Alleged Murderer; Jail

properties.Description: August: Unknown Mexican lynched for alleged killing of a cow.
properties.Source: San Antonio Ledger, 22 Aug 1857 as listed in Carrigan and Webb, Forgotten Dead.
properties.Target Classification: Mexican; Hispanic; Catholic; Alleged Criminal

properties.Description: September: Massacre of 120 emigrant whites by Mormons and Indians. Men and women and children killed. This occurred during the so-called Mormon war.
properties.Source: Brooks.Mountain Meadows Massacre
properties.Target Classification: White; Woman; Youth

properties.Description: October: More election rioting as know-nothings prevent immigrant from voting and win local elections. 11,898 to 2,792. In the 8th ward. Ser. William Jordan of the police killed.
properties.Source: Scharf.Chronicles, p.558-563; H+W, p.93
properties.Target Classification: Political; Democrat; Legal; Police

properties.Description: December: Regulators numbering about 400 strong captured Hiram Roberts, forced him to confess to counterfeiting then hagned him in a barn. Six of the mob were later charged, but case dropped.
properties.Source: Black. "Lynchings," p.198-199
properties.Target Classification: Alleged Criminal; Alleged Conterfeiter

properties.Description: Vigilantes capture and hang J.W. Thomas - a murderer.
properties.Source: Graham. "Vigilance Committee," Palinpsest 6, (1925) 362
properties.Target Classification: Alleged Criminal; Alleged Murderer

properties.Description: April: Plattsmouth vigilantes launch a raid against an alleged gang of horse thieves - the Johnson gang. The vigilantes siezed Mrs. Johnson when she attempted to cross the Missouri river and held her in custody. They then raided the Johnson residence, capturing a number of people. The vigilantes proceeded to drown three Johnson men and one Kelly in the Missouri river, and banished the rest to Iowa. A teacher, T.M. Marquett, reported to be among the vigilante ranks.
properties.Source: Olive Gass, The Vigilantes, Nebraska's First Defenders, Nebraska History Magazine, 3-18.
properties.Target Classification: Alleged Criminal; Alleged Thief; Alleged Horse Thief; Woman

properties.Description: May: Striking RR workers use violence to prevent trains from running. On the 1st they ambushed a train leaving Baltimore at a deep cuty at Jackson's bridge. Shots were exchanged with police. One train got through, three others did not. A similar confrontation occurred Sunday. Several strikers wounded both days, and on the 2nd one was killed. The rioters also spiked tracks. After 3rd some settlement was reached. Slight to workers.
properties.Source: Scharf.Chronicles, p.555-557
properties.Target Classification: Railroad

properties.Description: May: Crowd fires into house of Salmon Stebbins; he returns fire and kills Perley Childs. The crowd were involved in a Charivari - at least 25 involved.
properties.Source: Roth, "Notes"
properties.Target Classification: Unknown

properties.Description: August: Joe Shambeau, Jimmy, and Charles Gebabish allegedly murdered a man at Gull Lake. Two of the accused were described as Natives, and one was labeled a "half-breed." A group of Natives and some whites arrested the three, and Sheriff Poe (?) prepared to bring the three to authorities in St. Paul. En route, a group of white vigilantes intercepted the Sheriff and, holding him, seized the prisoners. They proceeded to lynch the men.
properties.Source: New York Times, September 7, 1857. Robert D. Pomperoy, "Morrison County's Only Lynching" (1966, unpublished manuscript, Minnesota Historical Society, St Paul); John D. Bessler, Legacy of Violence: Lynch Mobs and Executions in Minnesota (Minneapolis: University of Minnesota Press, 2003), 5; Ziebarth, "Judge Lynch in Minnesota," 72 as listed in Pfeifer, The Roots of Rough Justice.
properties.Target Classification: Native; Alleged Murderer; Legal; Sheriff
properties.Persons Named as Targets: Joe Shambeau; Jimmy; Charles Gebabish; Poe

properties.Description: January: Unknown Mexican hanged for alleged murder.
properties.Source: Brownsville Nueces Valley Weekly, 23. Jan 1858 as listed in Carrigan and Webb, Forgotten Dead.
properties.Target Classification: Mexican; Hispanic; Catholic; Alleged Criminal; Alleged Murderer

properties.Description: February: Jesus Anastasia lynched for alleged murder.
properties.Source: Nevada Journal, 26 Feb. 1858 as listed in Carrigan and Webb, Forgotten Dead.
properties.Target Classification: Mexican; Hispanic; Catholic; Alleged Criminal; Alleged Murderer

properties.Description: March: Carlos Martínez beaten and hanged for alleged assault on girl aged 8 or 9.
properties.Source: Sante Fe Weekly Gazette, 1 May 1858 as listed in Carrigan and Webb, Forgotten Dead.
properties.Target Classification: Mexican; Hispanic; Catholic; Alleged Criminal; Alleged Assailant

properties.Description: April: Eight free-soilers led by James Montgomery fire upon dragoons, killing two, and wounding four.
properties.Source: Nichols.Bleeding Kansas, p.224-225
properties.Target Classification: Dragoon

properties.Description: May: Unknown Mexican lynched for alleged murder.
properties.Source: Sante Fe Weekly Gazette, 15 May 1858 as listed in Carrigan and Webb, Forgotten Dead.
properties.Target Classification: Mexican; Hispanic; Catholic; Alleged Criminal; Alleged Murderer

properties.Description: May: On the 13th, Santos Peralta lynched for alleged murder.
properties.Source: Carrigan and Webb, Forgotten Dead.
properties.Target Classification: Mexican; Hispanic; Catholic; Alleged Criminal; Alleged Murderer

properties.Description: May: Marceis des Cygnes massacre. Proslavery forced under Charles Hamilton round up free-soil men. They take nine, formed a firing squad and shot them. Five were killed, four wounded, but pretended to be dead.
properties.Source: Nichols.Bleeding Kansas, p.227
properties.Type: Slavery; Vigilante; Law; Racial; Political; Land
properties.Target Classification: Free-Soiler; Anti-Slavery; Free-Stater

properties.Description: June: A committee of vigilance backed by one thousand men seized the state arsenal, the jail and large sections of the city. Well armed and with artillery they cowed local know-nothings officials. The committee wanted orderly elections. Know-nothing crowds wanted more action, and attempted an assault on the force with no success. After the election, which was peaceful, the committee disbanded its forces, although many leaders and some followers left the city. Some 11 people died during the action, at least 5 accidentally.
properties.Source: Asbury.French Quarter, p.298-314
properties.Target Classification: Nativist; Know Nothing; Political

properties.Description: December: John Brown leads a raid from Kansas along the Little Osege River. Captures 11 slaves, belonging to 3 families, and all other removeable property - horses and clothing taken from about a dozen families. They killed only one man in the process.
properties.Source: Nichols.Bleeding Kansas, p.235-236
properties.Target Classification: Pro-Slavery; Border Ruffian; Slaveholder
properties.Actions: Prison Break; Lethal Violence; Seized Property

properties.Description: January: McClain and McDougal hanged for alleged counterfeiting
properties.Source: New York Times, Janurary 30, 1858; February 8, 1858 as listed in Pfeifer, The Roots of Rough Justice.
properties.Target Classification: Alleged Criminal; Alleged Counterfeiter

properties.Description: March: Two alleged horse thieves, Harvey Braden and John Daley, were arrested and incarcerated in Omaha. A lynch mob gathered at the prison, seized the men, and proceeded to hang them.
properties.Source: Alfred R. Sorenson, Early History of Omaha (Omaha, NE: Daily Bee, 1876), 118.
properties.Target Classification: Alleged Criminal; Alleged Theif; Alleged Horse Theif; Legal; Jail

properties.Description: May: On the 29th, 40 masked men seized Nicanor Urdiales, Pablo Longoria, Francisco Huizan, and Felipe Lopez from Mission San Jose for alleged theft. The vigilantes lynched the men.
properties.Source: San Antonio Ledger, 12 June 1858 as listed in Carrigan and Webb, Forgotten Dead.
properties.Target Classification: Mexican; Hispanic; Catholic; Alleged Criminal; Alleged Thief
properties.Persons Named as Targets: Nicanor Urdiales; Pablo Longoria; Francisco Huizan; Felipe Lopez

properties.Description: May: Philip Clark and Boyd Wilkinson locked in a land dispute. Wilkinson had allegedly beaten Clark, arousing anger in the community. On May 10, Clark's barn burned down, and Clark and his friends suspect Wilkinson of arson. A committee met in Iowa City, with Henry Felkner president and Samuel McCory secretary. The committee authorized force. A group consisting of Clark, Henry Gray, F.M. Irish, Alfred Curtis, Charle Dow, Daniel Marshall, Samuel Shellady, G.W. Rawson, Charles Brown, James Taylor, John McGuire, and Peter Conboy siezed Wilkinson. At least thirty-five men were part of the vigilantes. Wilkinson drowned in the Iowa River. The men swore he jumped in himself, but lynching probable. No attempt was made to save Wilkinson. A court case followed, and the governor pardoned at least on of the vigilantes.
properties.Source: Erik McKinley Eriksson, "The Boyd Wilkinson Case," The Palimpset 6 (1925), 95-104.
properties.Target Classification: Squatter; Alleged Criminal; Alleged Arsonist
properties.Persons Named as Rioters: Philip Clark; Henry Gray; F.M. Irish; Alfred Curtis; Charle Dow; Daniel Marshall; Samuel Shellady; G.W. Rawson; Charles Brown; James Taylor; John McGuire; Peter Conboy; Henry Felkner; Samuel McCory

properties.Description: June: Land claim dispute turned deadly in Kansas between two Free-Soil men. Gaius (called Davis in paper) Jenkins was in the habit of fetching water from a well located on a disputed claim. Jenkins went to the well with an ax and four armed friends. James Lane, the other claimant, ordered Jenkins not to approach lest he be shot. Jenkins continued to advance, at which point Lane produced a shotgun and fired. 98 shot hit Jenkins in the breast, legs, and stomach, killing him. One of Jenkins's friends returned fire, hitting Lane in the leg. Lynching was threatened after, but the law intervened.
properties.Source: The Nebraska City News, June 12, 1858.
properties.Target Classification: Squatter; Free-Soiler

properties.Description: June: On the 12th, Pío Linares shot for alleged murder.
properties.Source: Carrigan and Webb, Forgotten Dead.

properties.Description: February: Members of a vigilance committee siezed W.W. "Pennsyltuck" Atkins from the bed where he was recuperating. He had been shot by Sheriff Kehler some weeks prior. The men hanged Atkins during the night. Claims appeared in the paper that the vigilantes only lynched Pennsyltuck because he was making murderous threats while recovering. Dr. Erdhmann, who had been treating the victim, denied these claims, and insisted that Pennsyltuck had only expressed sorrow and desire to reform.

properties.Description: July: Three black men - Pat Jennings, Sam Smith, and Cato - hanged for alleged insurrectionary plotting. A vigilance committee arrested and interrogated nearly one hundred black people. Rumors abounded that the hanged men planned to burn the town, kill the elderly, poison the people, and "to seize and to approproate the young and handsomest for their villainous purposes."
properties.Source: The Nebraska City News, August 25, 1860
properties.Target Classification: Black; Alleged Criminal; Alleged Arsonist

properties.Description: July: More rumors of poison and insurrection. White vigilance committee targets black population. Several lynchings occur - at least four, maybe more. Committee of Vigilance in session all day.
properties.Source: The Nebraska City News, August 25, 1860
properties.Target Classification: Black; Alleged Criminal; Alleged Arsonist

properties.Description: July: Carl Wood and two friends, irritated with the Rocky Mountain News, seized William N. Byers from his officer, and took him to Harrison's saloon. The men made threats against Byers's life, but Harrison helped him escape out a back door. Wood and a friend, George Steele, went to shoot Byers. Instead, Steele was shot and killed and Wood arrested. A People's Court tried Wood, defended by A.C. Ford. The court ordered Wood banished instead of lynched, to the chagrin of the News.
properties.Source: Leonard, Lynching in Colorado, 22.
properties.Target Classification: Press; Alleged Criminal
properties.Actions: Lethal Violence; Non-Lethal Violence; Seized Person(s); Threat

properties.Description: September: Vigilante court tries, convicts and sentences to hanging murderer James Gordon. A marshal took Gordon from Leavenworth to Denver for this purpose. Gordon was hanged on October 6th. The court had no legal basis. W.P. McLure served as Gordon's lawyer, William Larimer served as a judge.
properties.Source: Gower. "Vigilantes," Col. Mag., 41 (1941) 93-104 and Leonard, Lynching in Colorado, Table A.1
properties.Rioter Classification: Vigilante; Legal; Marshal; Law Officer; People's Court
properties.Target Classification: Alleged Criminal; Alleged Murderer

properties.Description: Authorities arrested James Bouve and John S. Iler for assualting and robbing a local woman. A crowd gathered, formed an extralegal committee, and interrogated both men in their cells. Iler confessed. An extrajudicial trial was then organized. Iler was granted leniancy, but the crowd voted to lynch Bouve. One man, Robert A. Howard, begged the crowd to let the law handle justice, but he was not heeded. Vigilantes stormed the jail and hanged Bouve from a ceiling beam. Iler was told to leave, and shots were fired at him, possibly to scare him, as he ran.
properties.Source: Sorenson, History of Omaha, 123.
properties.Target Classification: Legal; Jail; Marshal; Alleged Criminal

properties.Description: April: Union troops on their way to Washington and marching between train stations were attacked by mobs led by "Plug Uglies." Shots were exchanged. Casualties on both sides. 7 soldiers killed, 12 citizens killed.

properties.Description: Feburary: A mob siezed an enslaved man, George from jail, where he was being held for alleged rape or attempted rape. The mob burned George to death.

properties.Description: March: Trial of black man, Wm. Faulkner, for allegedly molesting a white and black girl elicits a great deal of attention. At one point during trial, when court visited the scene of the alleged crime, crowd hurled stoned at Faulkner. After he was convicted (he was innocent) on the 6th, Provost Marshall's men used to guard him on way to jail. Guards fired on threatening crowd, killing one man. Angered, whites later attacked black neighborhood, burning houses, assaulting blacks of both sexes. Concerns over draft also in (??).
properties.Source: Schneider. "Detroit…,"Michigan History58 (1974) p.4-24
properties.Target Classification: Black; Legal; Prisoner; Woman; Alleged Criminal; Alleged Sexual Assailant

properties.Description: May: Democratic supporters of Clement C. Vallandigham outraged by his arrest by the Army gathered outside pro-Democrat newspaprt office - Empire. About 200 strong they threw stones and fired pistols at window. They also hurled fired "turpentine balls." These caught on and destroyed the Journal building and half a block more. Rioters prevented firefighters from doing their duty. Soldiers arrived. One rioter killed while cutting firehose. Mob dispersed.
properties.Source: Klement.Copperheads, p.92
properties.Target Classification: Press; Firefighter; Political; Democrat; Military

properties.Description: May: Vigilantes from California Gulch tracked alleged murderers for twelve days. The alleged murderers were two Mexican men. The vigilantes killed one, and one escaped. The vigilantes, going through possessions left behind, found a book. An attempt to translate the Spanish led the Anglos to believe that the Mexican men were out to exterminate as many Americans as possible. The Anglos believed the Mexican men to be the Espinosa brothers
properties.Source: The Weekly Commonwealth, May 21, 1863
properties.Target Classification: Mexican; Hispanic; Catholic; Alleged Criminal; Alleged Murderer

properties.Description: June: Mob lynches black person for assaulting an Irish-American woman.
properties.Source: Anbinder, p.312
properties.Target Classification: Black; Alleged Criminal; Alleged Assailant

properties.Description: June: About 12 men ambushed enrolling officers for draft and killed a US marshall.
properties.Source: Coakley.Role, p.240
properties.Target Classification: Draft Officer

properties.Description: July: Mob hanged Ben Franks, a local cattleman, outside jail after officers had arrested him. Frank was charged with murder and robbery.
properties.Source: Sonnechison.10 Texas Feuds, p.81
properties.Target Classification: Prisoner; Legal

properties.Description: July: Draft riots. Start in protest of $300 exemption clause of draft. Includes attacks on homes and shops of the rich, but quickly black people become the main focus of rioters' wrath. African Americans lynched from light posts, homes and institutions destroyed. Concerted fight with authorities. Army ordered in and massive street battles ensue. At least 105 died.
properties.Source: Cook, Headley, Bernstein.
properties.Type: Racial; Anti-Draft; Draft; Political; Ethnic/National; Religious; War; Military; Political
properties.Rioter Classification: Anti-Draft; Anti-Abolitionist; Irish; Catholic; Woman; Youth
properties.Target Classification: Black; Abolitionist; Legal; Law Officer; Military; Reformer; Woman; Youth
properties.Actions: Lethal Violence; Non-Lethal Violence; Threat; Property Destroyed; Mutiliation

properties.Description: August: Mob of about 400 besieged office of local provost Marshall over the draft. Five people killed before military put down the riot.
properties.Source: Coakley.Role, p.262-263
properties.Target Classification: Draft Officer

properties.Description: August: Conflict between coscripts and neighboring farmers over trespassing. One farmer shot and killed.
properties.Source: Scharf and Wescott, p.809
properties.Target Classification: Farmer

properties.Description: November: Mob of miners broke into the home of George K. Smith and killed him. Smith, a mine operator, had apparently given a list of employees to a draft officer.
properties.Source: Aurand, p.98
properties.Type: Labor; Draft; Anti-Draft; Military; Political; War
properties.Target Classification: Mine Operator; Employer

properties.Description: November: Vigilantes active throughout the area to punish robbers and murderers who had hitherto been proected by the corrupt officers of the law. Thirty men hanged.
properties.Target Classification: Thief; Criminal

properties.Description: November: Crowd of 200 arrested 5 Anglo drifters who allegedly murdered a prospector and resisted arrest. All five lynched.
properties.Source: Blew. "Vigilantism," p.23
properties.Target Classification: White; Drifter; Anglo; Alleged Criminal; Alleged Murderer

properties.Description: December: Convicted murderer of an Anglo rancher, Manuel Cerredel, seized aboard steamer taking him to San Quinton and hanged from a yard arm.
properties.Source: Blew. "Vigilantism," p.24
properties.Target Classification: Prisoner; Legal; Mexican; Hispanic; Catholic; Alleged Murderer; Alleged Criminal

properties.Description: December: Charles Wilkens, convicted of murdering John Sanford, merchant, was dragged from the court room and hanged in a nearby corral.
properties.Source: Blew. "Vigilantism," p.24
properties.Target Classification: Prisoner; Legal; Alleged Murderer; Alleged Criminal

properties.Description: December: On the 26th, Luis Seyra and Cosmé Nuñez seized from authorities and killed for alleged murder.
properties.Source: House Ex. Doc #73^24 as listed in Carrigan and Webb, Forgotten Dead.
properties.Target Classification: Prisoner; Legal; Mexican; Hispanic; Catholic; Alleged Murderer; Alleged Criminal

properties.Description: June: Mob pelted provost Marshall with bricks, etc., and left him unconscious and dead in the street. Rioters were Irish and acted after two Irishmen had been arrested for failing to give named to enrolling officers. Several (??) involved.
properties.Source: Sterling. Journal of Illinois St. Hist., p.259; Klement.Copperheads, p.79
properties.Target Classification: Draft Officer

properties.Description: July: A man named Miller hanged for alleged horse theft
properties.Source: Black, "Lynchings in Iowa," 210 as listed in Pfeifer, The Roots of Rough Justice.
properties.Target Classification: Alleged Thief; Alleged Horse Thief

properties.Description: Vigilantes capture three horse thieves and organize their own informal trial. The vigilantes sentences all three men to death. One asked to be shot, but was hanged all the same. One wrote a note to his mother.
properties.Source: Olive Gass, The Vigilantes, Nebraska's First Defenders, Nebraska History Magazine, 3-18.
properties.Target Classification: Alleged Criminal; Alleged Thief; Alleged Horse Thief

properties.Description: September: US troops lynch 5 members of the Reynolds Gang for alleged theft.
properties.Source: Leonard, Lynching in Colorado, Table A.1
properties.Target Classification: Alleged Criminal; Alleged Thief; Gang

properties.Description: June: Haslet lynched for alleged theft and cheating.
properties.Source: Leonard, Lynching in Colorado, Table A.1
properties.Target Classification: Alleged Criminal; Alleged Thief; Alleged Cheat

properties.Description: January: Vigilante action against a gang of thieves and murderers. Henry Plummer, sheriff of Bannock and Virginia, led the criminal band. Vigilantes lynched Plummer, George Lane, George Ives, Ned Ray, Buck Stinson, John Wagner alias Dutch John, Red alias Bevens, Brown, Hayes Lyon, Jack Gallagher, Frank Parish, and Boone Helm. Joe Pizanthia, known as "Spanish Frank," hanged and corpse burned.
properties.Source: Bancroft, Popular Tribunals as listed in Carrigan and Webb, Forgotten Dead and "LYNCH LAW AMONG THE MORMONS" Glasgow Herald March 26, 1864
properties.Target Classification: Legal; Sheriff; Law Officer; Mexican; Hispanic; Catholic; Alleged Murderer; Alleged Criminal; Alleged Thief
properties.Persons Named as Targets: Joe "Spaniard Frank" Pizanthia;  Henry Plummer; George Lane; George Ives; Ned Ray; Buck Stinson; John "Dutch John" Wagner; Reed alias Bevens; Brown; Hayes Lyon; Jack Gallagher; Frank Parish; Boone Helm

properties.Description: February: On the 9th, Patrocinio Lopez lynched for alleged murder.
properties.Source: Monterey Gazette, 12 Feb 1864 as listed in Carrigan and Webb, Forgotten Dead.
properties.Target Classification: Mexican; Hispanic; Catholic; Alleged Murderer; Alleged Criminal

properties.Description: February: On the 18th, Jesús Arellanes lynched for alleged murder.
properties.Source: H. H. Bancroft, Reference Notes as listed in Carrigan and Webb, Forgotten Dead.
properties.Target Classification: Mexican; Hispanic; Catholic; Alleged Murderer; Alleged Criminal

properties.Description: February: Mob seized captured guerilla John F. Bolin and lynched him.
properties.Source: Fellman.Inside War, p.120
properties.Target Classification: Guerilla

properties.Description: February: Vigilantes take 4 men out of jail who had been accused of murder and hanged them. Subsequently they oredered out local toughs from the community.
properties.Source: McGrath.Gunfighters, p.94-97
properties.Target Classification: Prisoner; Legal; Alleged Murderer

properties.Description: February: Six soldiers and 14 copperheads fight as soldiers attempt to capture cache of arms. Two soldiers wounded, one copperhead killed.
properties.Source: Coleman and Spence. "Charleston Riot," p.17
properties.Target Classification: Copperhead; Political; Anti-War; Military; Union
properties.Actions: Lethal Violence; Non-Lethal Violence; Seized Property

properties.Description: February: John Seaman shot for alleged horse theft and arson
properties.Source: Black, "Lynchings in Iowa," 212 as listed in Pfeifer, The Roots of Rough Justice.
properties.Target Classification: Alleged Thief; Alleged Horse Thief; Alleged Arsonist

properties.Description: March: Fatal encounter - after a soldier shot a man who cheered Jeff Davis.
properties.Source: Gray.Hidden Civil War, p.165
properties.Target Classification: Copperhead; Political; Anti-War; Confederate Sympathizer

properties.Description: March: Riot occurs on court day between local copperheads and soldiers returning from furlough. Nine killed in gun battle that started as an argument between copperhead and soldiers. Six were soldiers, one a Republican bystander.
properties.Source: Coleman and Spence. "Charleston Riot"
properties.Rioter Classification: Copperhead; Political; Anti-War; Military; Union; Republican
properties.Target Classification: Copperhead; Political; Anti-War; Military; Union; Republican

properties.Description: June: Vigilantes shot and clubbed to death José Aniceto Baldenbro and Simon Montoya for not cooperating with them.
properties.Source: Virginia Daily Union (Virginia City), 14 June 1864 as listed in Carrigan and Webb, Forgotten Dead.
properties.Target Classification: Mexican; Hispanic; Catholic

properties.Description: July: Lager-beer saloon at Tenth ave. Brawl turned into a battle with police. One man killed, six arrested.
properties.Source: Cook.Armies, p.19
properties.Target Classification: Legal; Police

properties.Description: August: Pat Brady shot Lynch while trying to shoot Murphy. The miners organized a hasty trial and lynched Brady that evening. Jem Kelly was deemed an accessory to murder and given fifty lashes.
properties.Source: The Rocky Mountain News, August 27, 1864 and Dimdsale, The Vigilantes of Montana, 192
properties.Target Classification: Alleged Criminal; Alleged Murderer; Alleged Accessory; Irish; Catholic
properties.Actions: Lethal Violence; Non-Lethal Violence; Seized Person(s)

properties.Description: Septeber: The "vigies" caught Jem Kelly for stealing a mule and hanged him. They had previously given Kelly fifty lashes for accessory to murder.
properties.Source: The Rocky Mountain News, September 21, 1864 and Dimsdale, The Vigilantes of Montana, 192
properties.Target Classification: Alleged Criminal; Alleged Thief; Irish; Catholic

properties.Description: September: Unknown Mexican lynched for alleged theft.
properties.Source: Sacramento Union, 23 Sept 1864 as listed in Carrigan and Webb, Forgotten Dead.
properties.Target Classification: Mexican; Hispanic; Catholic; Alleged Thief; Alleged Criminal

properties.Description: September: Unknown Mexican lynched for alleged theft.
properties.Source: Sacramento Union, 23 Sept 1864 as listed in Carrigan and Webb, Forgotten Dead.
properties.Target Classification: Mexican; Hispanic; Catholic

properties.Description: December: Pvt. Charles Lockman murdered Pvt. John Groce, both of the Second Colorado Cavalry. Disregarding military regulations, the rest of the men, lead by Lt. Wise, organized their own trial and lynched Lockman. Wise would be court martialed, but recieved a remitted sentence.
properties.Source: Christopher Rein, The Second Colorado Cavalry: A Civil War Regiment on the Great Plains (Norman: University of Oklahoma Press, 2020), 37.
properties.Target Classification: Military; Alleged Criminal; Alleged Murderer

properties.Description: January: Some black soldiers, joined by local black people, foght with whites over "a widow lady…who at the time had several young ladies staying with her." Other Union soldiers quelled the riot, but not until six African Americans had been killed or mortally wounded. The riot followed rumors that some Irishmen had attacks black people.
properties.Source: Garson and O'Brien, p.247
properties.Rioter Classification: Black; White; Military; Irish; Catholic; Woman; Prostitute; Brothel
properties.Target Classification: Black; White; Military; Irish; Catholic; Woman; Prostitute; Brothel

properties.Description: September: Confederate guerillas killed one black person, tortured some, and robbed others.
properties.Source: Garson and O'Brien, p.247
properties.Target Classification: Black
properties.Actions: Lethal Violence; Non-Lethal Violence; Threat; Seized Property

properties.Description: December: Riot on Christmas Day between white and black people. 14 black people and 2 white people killed.
properties.Source: Garson and O'Brien, p.247; Hennessey, p.17
properties.Target Classification: White; Black

properties.Description: April: A teamster, Fox, murdered a man named Eldred en route to Colorado. Members of the 17th Kansas captrued Fox and brought him to Kearney, where a "people's court"  sentenced him to hanging. Fox requested the sheriff of the people's court shoot him instead, and refused both blindfold and hand bindings. The sheriff accomodated these wishes, and "the fiend thus atoned blood for blood, as he deserved."
properties.Source: The Rocky Mountain News, April 11, 1865
properties.Target Classification: Alleged Criminal; Alleged Murderer

properties.Description: April: Angered by horse and cattle theft, the citizens of Walla Walla formed a vigilance committee. The vigilantes proceeded to hang 15 men. Doc. Reed, "N***** Jim," McKenzie, Tom Reeves, Charles Wilson, and Joseph Petis all named as victims of the lynching. The newspaper does not condem the action.
properties.Source: Seattle Weekly Gazzette, April 27 1865. Also listed in Pfeifer, The Roots of Rough Justice.
properties.Target Classification: Alleged Criminal; Alleged Thief; Alleged Horse Thief; Alleged Cattle Thief; Black
properties.Persons Named as Targets: Doc. Reed; N***** Jim; McKenzie; Tom Reeves; Charles Wilson; Joseph Petis

properties.Description: May: Hanging of James Henderson for alleged horse theft and threat to blow up the treasurer's office
properties.Source: Black, "Lynchings in Iowa," 217
properties.Target Classification: Alleged Thief; Alleged Horse Thief; Anti-Government

properties.Description: May: John Campbell, a Native man, hanged for alleged murder.
properties.Source: Ziebarth, "Judge Lynch in Minnesota," 72 as listed in Pfeifer, The Roots of Rough Justice.
properties.Target Classification: Native; Alleged Criminal; Alleged Murderer

properties.Description: May: Juan Higuera, the son of 1854 victim, lynched for alleged murder of a deputy.
properties.Source: Monterey Gazette, 19 May 1865 as listed in Carrigan and Webb, Forgotten Dead.
properties.Target Classification: Mexican; Hispanic; Catholic; Alleged Murderer; Alleged Criminal

properties.Description: June: Man named Lacey hanged for alleged theft
properties.Source: Black, "Lynchings in Iowa," 217-218 as listed in Pfeifer, The Roots of Rough Justice.
properties.Target Classification: Alleged Thief

properties.Description: July: Men from New York regiment fought with black soldiers in the 21st US colored troops. Fighting began with a shooting skirmish at the market place on the 8th. Ended with New Yorkers ordered out of the city. At least one black person killed.
properties.Source: Williamson.After Slavery, p.258
properties.Target Classification: Black; White; Military; New Yorker

properties.Description: July: Hanging of a man named "White" for alleged murder and arson
properties.Source: New York Times, July 16, 1865 as listed in Pfeifer, The Roots of Rough Justice.
properties.Target Classification: Alleged Criminal; Alleged Murderer; Alleged Arsonist

properties.Description: August: Hanging of man named Miller for alleged murderous assault
properties.Source: New York Times, August 5, 1865 as listed in Pfeifer, The Roots of Rough Justice.
properties.Target Classification: Alleged Criminal; Alleged Murderer; Alleged Arsonist

properties.Description: August: Hispanic man labeled "Mexican" hanged for alleged horse theft
properties.Source: Seatte Weekly, August 26, 1865 as listed in Pfeifer, The Roots of Rough Justice.
properties.Target Classification: Alleged Criminal; Alleged Murderer; Alleged Arsonist

properties.Description: October: Hanging of James Hiner for alleged horse theft
properties.Source: Black, "Lynchings in Iowa," 219 as listed in Pfeifer, The Roots of Rough Justice.
properties.Target Classification: Alleged Thief; Alleged Horse Thief

properties.Description: October: Two alleged horse thieves - John Morgan and John Jackson - lynched by Vigilance Committee. To their corpse was pinned the warning "Road Agents beware."
properties.Source: The Rocky Mountian News, October 20, 1865 and Dimsdale, The Vigilante of Montana 106 and Dillon, The Montana Vigilantes 1863–1870, 187
properties.Target Classification: Alleged Thief; Alleged Criminal; Alleged Horse Thief
